items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
"River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.7mAOD at 04:30 on 21/08/24 and 4.6mAOD at 16:45 on 21/08/24.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 26 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 18:30 on 21/08/24, or as the situation changes."

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force due to strong winds, surge and high spring tides on the coast. Areas most at risk include the North Sea coast from Skipsea to Mappleton, including Hornsea. Flooding is possible between 06:30 and 08:30 tomorrow, Thursday 22/08/2024. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts / warnings. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 21:00 on Wednesday 21/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
A flood alert has been issued as a series of high tides are expected over the next 3 days. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. Locations that may be affected include areas river side of defences where defences are present including Lydney Harbour. Low lying land at Purton on the east bank may also be impacted. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. 
Predicted peaks. 
Avonmouth 7.7m to 7.9m at 21:30 on 21/08/2024, and 7.5m to 7.8m at 09:45 on 22/08/2024.
Sharpness 9.9m to 10.3m at 23:30 on 21/08/2024, and 9.8m to 10.2m at 10:45 on 22/08/2024. 
Flooding is not forecast at other gauge sites. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 2pm on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tides from Wednesday 21st August, Thursday 22nd August to Friday 23rd August. High water at Ilfracombe on Wednesday evening is at 20:15 BST. Times of high water will vary along the coast.
 
Force 6 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 2m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.  Expect tides to be around 130mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it;
The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe on Wednesday evening is 5.26 mAOD, this is 0.13 metres above astronomical tide level.
The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe on Thursday morning is 5.10 mAOD, this is 0.26 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: Mersey Estuary from Liverpool and Wirral to Widnes

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Halton, Knowsley, Liverpool, Sefton, Wirral

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast in the early hours of tomorrow morning, 21/08/2024.    

Flooding is possible at low lying lands and roads from 01:00 AM on 21/08/2024 at the following location: 

Hale Village, peaking at 01:00am. 

We currently do not anticipate the Flood Alert level to be met during the next high tide around midday tomorrow. However, we are expecting the Flood Alert to be met during the early hours of Thursday and Friday. Flood Warnings may also be issued for these high tides.  

 Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation.    

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.    

This message will be updated tomorrow or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message: A flood alert has been issued as a result of high tides, flooding is expected over the next 4 days with tides peaking Thursday evening 22/08/24. Conditions may apply for an hour either side of high tide. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. Predicted peaks today Tuesday evening 20/08/24:- Newport 7.0m to 7.3m at 20:45. Avonmouth Portbury 7.3m to 7.6m at 20:45.  No thresholds are expected to be crossed on Wednesday mornings tide but they are rising again for Wednesday evening.  We are closely monitoring the situation. Please stay away from large waves as they are dangerous. This message will be updated by 11:00 on Wednesday, 21/08/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lune estuary south west of Lancaster
items.message:
High tides this evening may lead to flooding.
Flooding is possible with the midday tide today 21/08/2024, but not expected.
However, further flooding is possible on the overnight tide tonight, 21/08/2024 into tomorrow 22/08/2024 due to spring tides and strong winds over the next few days. The flood alert remains in place.
Areas most at risk include Aldcliffe Marsh, Heaton Marsh, Marsh, Greyhound Bridge, Skerton Bridge, Newton, Overton, Middleton, Glasson, Conder Green, Conder Bridge and Thurnham Moss.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Take care along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 5pm on 21/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Clevedon
items.message:
Flooding is possible this evening and tomorrow morning in response to high tides from 21/08/2024 at 8.30 PM along the coastline between Gullhouse Point and Marine Parade. Flooding of coastal roads and foothpaths are possible, property flooding is not expected.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth. The first forecast high water is at 8:30 PM on 21/08/2024 with a level of 7.77 mAODN with south -westerly strong breeze force 5 winds.  The second high water is at 09:00 AM on 22/08/2024 with a level of 7.68 mAODN with a south-westerly strong force 7 winds.  Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. No property flooding is expected
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
Areas most at risk include the coastline between Gullhouse Point and Marine Parade.
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast in the early hours of tomorrow morning, 21/08/2024.   

Flooding is possible at low lying lands and roads from 01:00 AM on 21/08/2024 at the following locations:   

Fiddlers Ferry, peaking around 01:00 AM  

Eastford Road, peaking around 01:30 AM   

Arpley Bridge and Knutsford Road, peaking around 01:45 AM  

It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge.      

We currently do not anticipate the Flood Alert level to be met during the next high tide around midday tomorrow. However, we are expecting the Flood Alert to be met during the early hours of the morning on Thursday and Friday. Flood Warnings may also be issued for these high tides. 

Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation.   

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.   

This message will be updated tomorrow or as the situation changes

items.description: Irish Sea from Hilbre Island to Heswall
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the possibility of spray overtopping on the coast from early hours of tomorrow morning 21/08/2024. 

Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads from Hilbre Island and along the coast from West Kirby to Heswall from 01:00am 21/08/2024. No flooding to property is expected.  

We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings.  

Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation. 

Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. 

This message will be updated tomorrow or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Hornsea

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

items.message: This Flood Warning remains in force due strong winds, surge and high spring tides. Wave and spray overtopping is possible tomorrow, Thursday 22/08/2024, between 06:30 and 08:30. This could cause some localised flooding. Areas most at risk of flooding include Marine Drive, along South Promenade, Hornsea Burton Road and along Stream Dike and Foss Beck. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the coming days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 21:00 on Wednesday 21/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force due to strong winds, surge and high spring tides on the coast. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads in the Spurn Road, Southfield Farm and Kilnsea Caravan park areas. Flooding of coastal roads and footpaths along coast frontages is likely. Flooding is possible between 6:15AM and 9:30AM tomorrow, Thursday 22/08/2024. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9:00PM on Wednesday 21/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message: Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves, and spray overtopping on the coast between 7am to 11am, tomorrow morning, 22/08/24.  Areas most at risk are around Hunstanton seafront.  Flood gates in the area will be closed by the Local Authority which will make access difficult. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of 4:17 mAODN at 9.00am, on Thursday 22 August 2024, which is -0.47m above tide tables, wind Force 7, South-Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  The following tide on Friday 23 August 2024 at 9:15 am is currently forecast to be a Flood Alert. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. We are continuing to monitor the situation.  We will update this message by 11 am tomorrow, Thursday 22 August.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message: High spring tides are forecast over the coming days. First forecast high water is 20:45 BST on 20/08/2024 with a level of 7.40 mAOD and a Force 5 Westerly wind. Times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. There is a possibility of high water levels for the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible but properties are not expected to flood at this point. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff will be on site closing flood gates. Tomorrow morning’s tide is not forecast to reach flood alert thresholds. Be careful along beaches and low lying coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated by tomorrow, Wednesday 21st August 2024.

items.description: Tyne estuary

floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside, South Tyneside

items.message:
High tides are expected due to a combination of high spring tides and a storm surge from broader weather systems over the UK. Strong winds may cause large waves within the estuary tomorrow morning, 21/08/2024. Tides will be at their highest between 4:45AM and 5:15AM, 21/08/2024 with wave overtopping possible during these times. The area most likely to be affected is Newcastle Quayside.

This alert is in force for the high tides Wednesday (21/08/2024) Thursday (22/08/2024) and Friday morning (23/08/2024). High tides are anticipated between 05:15AM and 06:00AM, 22/08/2024 and 05:15AM and 07:15AM, 23/08/2024. The flood risk impacts will be highest on the Friday morning tide, 23/08/2024. Please remain vigilant for any potential flood warnings around Newcastle Quayside. 

We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please stay away from riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads as high water levels, large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message:
Flooding is possible this evening and tomorrow morning in response to high tides at Porlock Weir.

Highest tide level is expected to be at the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir at 8:30 PM on 20/08/2024. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. No property flooding is expected.

The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Hinkley Point. The first forecast high water is at 8:30 PM on 20/08/2024 with a level of 6.41 mAODN with westerly force 5 winds. The second forecast high water is at 8:45 AM on 21/08/2024, with a level of 6.19 mAODN and south-westerly force 4 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.)

Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

This flood alert is expected to remain in force during this high tide sequence up to and including the high tide at 22:30 on 23/08/2024. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 21/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 12:45 and 14:45, Wednesday 21st August.  Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides.  Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray.  The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.75 mAODN at 13:45,  Wednesday 21st August,  which is 0.17m above tide tables,  wind Force 5,  in a south westerly direction  (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 10:30 tomorrow, Thursday 22nd August.

items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message: High tides overnight tonight may lead to flooding. Flooding is also possible with the midday tide today, 21/08/2024, but not expected. However, flooding is possible on the tide tonight, 21/08/2024 into tomorrow, 22/08/2024, due to spring tides and strong winds overnight. Therefore the flood alert remains in place and a flood warning may be issued this afternoon. Areas most at risk include Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale. We have closed the flood gates at Arnside promenade, these will remain closed throughout the high tide cycle. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 6:00 PM on 21/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Northumberland coast
items.message:
High tides and strong winds may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning, 21/08/2024. Tides will be at their highest between 05:00AM and 06:00AM, 21/08/2024 with wave overtopping possible during these times. The areas most likely to be affected are Newbiggin Bay North Promenade and Beadnell Harbour Road North.  

This alert is in force for the high tides Wednesday (21/08/2024) Thursday (22/08/2024) and Friday morning (23/08/2024). High tides are anticipated between 05:00AM and 06:45AM, 22/08/2024 and 05:45AM and 07:45AM, 23/08/2024. The flood risk impacts will be highest on the Friday morning tide, 23/08/2024.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. 

This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

This alert is in force for the high tides Wednesday (21/08/2024) Thursday (22/08/2024) and Friday morning (23/08/2024). High tides are anticipated between 04:45AM and 06:00AM, 22/08/2024 and 05:30AM and 06:45AM, 23/08/2024. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

items.description: The tidal Deben estuary
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 12:45 and 14:45, Wednesday 21st August.  Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides.  Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.51 mAODN at 13:45,  Wednesday 21st August,  which is 0.33m above tide tables,  wind Force 5,  in a south westerly direction  (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 10:30 tomorrow, Thursday 22nd August.

items.description: Somerset coast at Minehead, Bridgwater, Burnham-on-Sea and Uphill to Kingston Seymour
items.message:
Flooding is possible this evening in response to a high tide on 21/08/2024 at 8.00 PM at Minehead, Combwich, Bridgwater, Burnham-on-Sea, Uphill, Weston-super-Mare, Kewstoke, Sand Bay and Kingston Seymour.

The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Hinkley Point. The forecast high water is at 8:00 PM on 21/08/2024 with a level of 6.77 mAODN with southerly moderate breeze force 4 winds. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. No property flooding is expected

Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

We will be monitoring the high tide and closing gates at Brean and Weston-super-Mare as required.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

Newport 7.3m to 7.6m at 21:30 on 21/08/2024 and 7.2m to 7.5m at 09:45 on 22/08/2024.
Avonmouth Portbury 7.7 to 7.9m at 21:30 on 21/08/2024 and 7.5 to 7.8m at 09:45 on 22/08/2024. 
   
levels are rising and conditions may apply a few hours either side of the high tide. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  Please avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 2pm on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes

items.description: Tidal Fal Estuary
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: South Cornwall Coast, Tidal Fal Estuary

items.message:
Flooding is possible over the evening high tides of Wednesday 21 August and Thursday 22 August. 
High water at Falmouth is at 7.30pm on Wednesday and 8.12pm on Thursday, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Force 5 south westerly winds are forecast to cause flooding of waterside locations and roads.  
Locations particularly at risk include low lying areas in Falmouth, Penryn, Flushing, Mylor Bridge, the A39 at Perranarworthal, Devoran, Calenick, Truro and the A390 at Tresillian.
The tidal gates at Flushing will be closed.
Do not walk or drive through flood water.  
We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by 12pm on Thursday 22 August, or earlier if the situation changes. 
Detailed tidal information:
Wednesday: Forecast high tide level at Falmouth is 2.60m AOD.  
Thursday: Forecast high tide level at Falmouth is 2.64m AOD. 
Expect tide levels along to coast to be between 60mm - 70mm above tide table level.
